case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Managing Agent of Keshav Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 167 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 167 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 15, 1955 of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 29 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 15, 1955 of the Bombay High Court in

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on February 17, 1960 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. February 17 The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this appeal is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the respondent is a partnership firm

facts.text: Respondent is a partnership firm appointed Managing Agent of Keshav Mills Ltd., Petlad by agreement dated September 23, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: which, by an agreement dated September 23, 1935, was appointed the Managing Agent of the Keshav Mills Ltd., Petlad.

facts.text: By clause 4 of agreement, Managing Agent entitled to 4% commission on sale proceeds of cloth, yarn or other goods manufactured and sold, and 15% on bills for ginning, pressing, dyeing, bleaching, labour bills etc.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 4 of this agreement the Managing Agent was to get a companymission of 4 on the sale proceeds of the cloth, yarn or other goods manufactured and sold by the companypany and 15 on the amount of bills for charges

facts.text: Commission exclusive of adat, interest, discount, brokerage etc.

anchor.surface_text: The companymission was exclusive of other charges such as adat, interest, discount, brokerage etc. The amount of companymission

facts.text: Commission credited every six months with 6% interest per annum.

anchor.surface_text: was to be credited in the account of the Managing Agent every six months and it was entitled to interest at the rate of six per cent. per annum

facts.text: Total commission for accounting year 1950 was Rs. 3,09,114.

anchor.surface_text: The total companymission for the accounting year 1950 was a sum of Rs. 3,09,114.

facts.text: During accounting year 1950, at oral request of Board of Directors of Managed Company, Managing Agent agreed to accept only Rs. 1,00,000 as commission.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime during the accounting year, at the oral request of the Board of Directors of the Managed Company, the Managing Agent agreed to accept a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 only as its companymission

facts.text: Rs. 1,00,000 credited to Managing Agent in books of company at end of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: which was credited to the account of the Managing Agent in the books of the companypany at the end of the year 1950.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 3,09,114 accrued and taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the amount which accrued as companymission to the Managing Agent was Rs. 3,09,114 and that amount was taxable.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 3,09,114 taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the amount which accrued as companymission to the Managing Agent was Rs. 3,09,114 and that amount was taxable.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated February 26, 1953 held Rs. 3,09,114 accrued but accepted Rs. 1,00,000 as taxable income and Rs. 2,09,114 allowable under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by the Managing Agent. By an order dated February 26, 1953, the Appellate Tribunal held that the amount which accrued to the Managing Agent

facts.text: Tribunal noted that in past, Managing Agent waived portion of commission in interest of Managed Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its order said that in the past also the Managing Agent had, in the interest of the Managed Company, waived a portion of the Commission

facts.text: At instance of appellant, Tribunal stated case to Bombay High Court on two questions.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order, at the instance of the appellant, a case was stated to the Bombay High Court for its opinion on the following two questions

facts.text: Question 1: Whether Rs. 2,09,114 assessable as income of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 2,09,114 was assessable in the hands of the assessee as its income.

facts.text: Question 2: If yes, whether allowable under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: If the answer to question i is in the affirmative whether the said sum is an allowable deduction from the assessees income under Section 10 2 xv of the Act.

facts.text: High Court directed Tribunal to submit supplementary statement at instance of Managing Agent.

anchor.surface_text: but at the instance of the Managing Agent the Appellate Tribunal was directed to submit a supplementary Statement.

facts.text: Managing Agent sent letter dated September 18, 1951 to ITO stating only Rs.1,00,000 accrued due to variation of terms, nothing foregone.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that some emphasis was laid on a letter of the Managing Agent dated September 18, 1951, sent to the Income-tax Officer. In this letter the Managing, Agent had stated that the only companymission

facts.text: Balance Sheet of Managed Company as on Dec 31, 1950: paid up capital Rs.30 lakhs, depreciation fund Rs.14 lakhs, total Rs.44 lakhs; Block Account debit over Rs.48 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made in the letter to the Balance Sheet of the Managed Company ending December 31, 1950, showing that the paid up capital was rupees 30 lacs, depreciation fund rupees 14 lacs,

facts.text: Chairman requested Managing Agent to accept Rs.1 lakh to strengthen financial position.

anchor.surface_text: As against this sum the Block Account showed a debit of over rupees 48 lacs and it was with the object of strengthening the financial position of the Managed Company

facts.text: Tribunal supplementary statement dated May 3, 1954: no oblique motive, remission bona fide, expenditure for business of Managing Agent, commercial expediency, interests linked.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal submitted a, supplementary Statement of Case dated May 3, 1954, in which it said 1 that there was numberoblique motive in accepting Rs. 1,00,000 instead of rupees 3 lacs

facts.text: Past: Managing Agent remitted part or whole commission when profits unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: the basic facts which arise out of the Statement of the Case and the documents which were produced by the Managing Agent are 1 the rather unsatisfactory financial position

facts.text: Year of account profits per P&L: Rs.5,72,192 after Rs.1,00,000 commission; if full commission deducted, Rs.3,63,078 lowest since 1940.

anchor.surface_text: in the year of account the profits of the managed companypany as per profit and loss account were Rs. 5,72,192. This was after paying to the Managing Agent a companymission of Rs. 1,00,000

facts.text: Not a bounty; accepted at instance of Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: it was number a bounty by the Managing Agent to the Managed Company 5 the business of the Managing Agent was so linked up with the Managed Company

facts.text: Bombay High Court by judgment dated February 15, 1955 held Tribunal finding as fact, answered in favour of Managing Agent.

anchor.surface_text: On this statement the High Court by its judgment dated February 15, 1955, held the finding of the Appellate Tribunal to be one of fact.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment and order that the. appellant has companye in appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Tribunal finding: amount foregone laid out wholly and exclusively for purpose of assessee's business.

anchor.surface_text: This was the material on which the Tribunal gave a finding in its suppementary Statement I that what was given up by the assessee was an expenditure

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal finding supported by evidence, deductible under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the finding is that it was laid out for the purpose of the assessees business and there is evidence to support this finding.

facts.text: Supreme Court: expenditure for commercial expediency, benefits assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal has found in favour of the Managing Agent that the amount was expended for reasons of companymercial expediency

arguments.claim: Expenditure deductible if for purpose of assessee's trade even if benefits third party.

anchor.surface_text: the real test laid down after reference to Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 1  was that deduction may be allowed in cases where the payment or expenditure is incurred for the purpose of the trade of the subject making the return and it does number matter that this payment may inure to the benefit of a third party.

arguments.claim: Transaction deductible if part of legitimate commercial undertaking for commercial expediency even if third party benefits.

The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  2  .

arguments.claim: Amount expended for commercial expediency to strengthen Managed Company, benefiting assessee; not bounty; deductible under s.10(2)(xv).

holdings.text: The amount foregone qualifies as deductible expenditure under s.10(2)(xv) as it was expended for reasons of commercial expediency to strengthen the managed company, benefiting the assessee.

holdings.text: Deduction allowable under s.10(2)(xv) even if expenditure inures to benefit of third party, if incurred for purpose of assessee's trade.

holdings.text: Expenditure voluntarily incurred on grounds of commercial expediency to indirectly facilitate carrying on of business is wholly and exclusively for purpose of trade under s.10(2)(xv).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Atherton case confirms voluntary payments for commercial expediency deductible even without direct immediate benefit.

holdings.text: The Tribunal rightly concluded that the foregone amount is deductible under s.10(2)(xv) based on its finding of commercial expediency.

anchor.surface_text: That finding is one of fact. On that finding the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rightly came to the conclusion that it was a deductible expense under s. 10 2  xv .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative findings on fact, evidence, and application of commercial expediency test justify deduction.

precedents.cited_proposition: Voluntary payment by managing agent towards bonus to managed company's officers to increase efficiency, profits and thereby own commission is deductible under s. 10(2)(xv)
precedents.cited_holding: Deduction allowed as per commercial principles with nexus between managed and managing agent

precedents.cited_holding: Expenditure must benefit assessee's trade directly, not reflex or indirect

anchor.surface_text: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  2  where a private limited companypany had a share capital of rupees 250 lacs of which shares of the value of rupees 50 lacs were held by A and the remaining by his numberinees.

precedents.case_name: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Transaction for commercial expediency deductible even if benefits shareholder/third party, if no fraud
precedents.cited_holding: Interest on debentures issued to shareholder deductible as business expenditure

anchor.surface_text: In Odhams Press Ltd. v. Cook 1  the assessee companypany had acquired all the shares in a subsidiary companypany and printed and published a periodical for the subsidiary companypany. The subsidiary companypany made a loss during the accounting year and the assessee companypany wrote off that amount of loss

precedents.cited_proposition: Writing off subsidiary's loss not deductible as not wholly for assessee's trade
precedents.cited_holding: Trade of subsidiary not same as assessee's trade

precedents.citation: Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 1

anchor.surface_text: Another test is whether the transaction is properly entered into as a part of the assessees legitimate companymercial undertaking in order to facilitate the carrying on of its business and it is immaterial that a third party also benefits thereby  Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 1  .

precedents.case_name: Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment may inure to benefit of third party but deductible if for assessee's trade

precedents.citation: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  2

precedents.case_name: Eastern Investments Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Immaterial if third party benefits if transaction part of assessee's commercial undertaking

precedents.cited_proposition: Expenditure voluntarily on commercial expediency indirectly facilitating trade is wholly for trade purpose

justification_sets.label: Wholly and Exclusively for Business Test support

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal has found in favour of the Managing Agent that the amount was expended for reasons of commercial expediency, it was not given as a bounty but to strengthen the Managed Company and if the financial position of the Managed Company became strong the Managing Agent would benefit thereby. That finding is one of fact. On that finding the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rightly came to the conclusion that it was a deductible expense under s. 10 2  xv .
